title: 111_hr6309
content: The Act is titled the "Notification of Origin of Telecommunications and Internet Consumer Exchanges Act of 2010" or the "NOTICE Act of 2010". Definitions are provided in Section 2. In this Act, definitions are provided for terms such as business entity, commerce, consumer, and customer service communication. The curr_chunk defines terms related to customer service communication, including telecommunication and wire communication. It explains the transmission of information without changing its form or content. Business entities engaged in customer service communications must disclose their physical location. Business entities must disclose their physical location at the beginning of customer service communications, with exceptions for those located in the United States or when communication is initiated by the consumer to a foreign entity. Business entities must disclose their physical location at the beginning of customer service communications, with exceptions for those located in the United States or when communication is initiated by the consumer to a foreign entity. The requirements do not apply to emergency services, and the Federal Trade Commission may exclude certain business entities or communications based on compelling circumstances. Each year, participating business entities must certify their compliance with customer service communication regulations. The Federal Trade Commission may exclude business entities from the disclosure requirements under compelling circumstances. Each year, businesses must certify their compliance with customer service communication regulations. The Commission will promulgate necessary regulations within a year of the Act's enactment, and the requirements will apply to communications one year after the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. ENFORCEMENT. Any failure to comply with section 3 of the Act will be treated as a violation of FTC regulations regarding unfair or deceptive acts. The FTC has the power to prevent violations of the Act and impose penalties on violators as per the Federal Trade Commission Act. The Act grants the Federal Trade Commission the same authority, jurisdiction, and duties as outlined in the Federal Trade Commission Act. This Act does not limit the FTC's authority under any other law.
